entry.title: 27.Remove Element
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®

Given an array nums and a value val, remove all instances of that value in-place and return the new length.

Do not allocate extra space for another array, you must do this by modifying the input array in-place with O(1) extra memory.

The order of elements can be changed. It doesnâ€™t matter what you leave beyond the new length.

Example 1:

Example 2:

é¢˜è§£

åŒæŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œå¿«æ…¢æ“ä½œ

  • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(n)$

  • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(1)$
entry.summary:
é¢˜ç›®

Given an array nums and a value val, remove all instances of that value in-place and return the new length.

Do not allocate extra space for another array, you must do this by modifying the input array in-place with O(1) extra memory.

The order of elements can be changed. It doesnâ€™t matter what you leave beyond the new length.

entry.title: 26.Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®

Given a sorted array nums, remove the duplicates in-place such that each element appear only once and return the new length.

Do not allocate extra space for another array, you must do this by modifying the input array in-place with O(1) extra memory.

Example 1:

Example 2:

entry.title: 25.Reverse Nodes in k-Group
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®

Given a linked list, reverse the nodes of a linked list k at a time and return its modified list.

k is a positive integer and is less than or equal to the length of the linked list. If the number of nodes is not a multiple of k then left-out nodes in the end should remain as it is.

Example:

Given this linked list: 1->2->3->4->5

For k = 2, you should return: 2->1->4->3->5

For k = 3, you should return: 3->2->1->4->5

Note:

  • Only constant extra memory is allowed.
  • You may not alter the values in the listâ€™s nodes, only nodes itself may be changed.

é¢˜è§£

ç”¨kå¤§å°çš„æ•°ç»„å­˜èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œå¹¶ä¾æ¬¡ç¿»è½¬

  • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(k)â€‹$
  • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(n)â€‹$

åªä½¿ç”¨å¸¸æ•°ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„åšæ³•

  • é—®é¢˜çš„å…³é”®åœ¨äºå¦‚ä½•åè½¬ä¸€ä¸ªkå¤§å°çš„é“¾è¡¨ï¼›è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨çš„æ˜¯å°†æ¯æ¬¡çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ’åˆ°æœ«å°¾çš„åšæ³•ã€‚
  • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(n)$
  • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(1)â€‹$
entry.summary:
é¢˜ç›®

Given a linked list, reverse the nodes of a linked list k at a time and return its modified list.

k is a positive integer and is less than or equal to the length of the linked list. If the number of nodes is not a multiple of k then left-out nodes in the end should remain as it is.

entry.title: 20.Valid Parentheses
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®

Given a string containing just the characters '(', ')', '{', '}', '['and ']', determine if the input string is valid.

An input string is valid if:

  1. Open brackets must be closed by the same type of brackets.
  2. Open brackets must be closed in the correct order.

Note that an empty string is also considered valid.

é¢˜ç›®

An input string is valid if:

Note that an empty string is also considered valid.

entry.title: 18.4Sum

entry.title: 17.Letters Combinations of a Phone Number
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®

Given a string containing digits from 2-9 inclusive, return all possible letter combinations that the number could represent.

A mapping of digit to letters (just like on the telephone buttons) is given below. Note that 1 does not map to any letters.

Example:

Note:

Although the above answer is in lexicographical order, your answer could be in any order you want.

é¢˜è§£

é€’å½’+å›æº¯

  • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(3^n4^m)â€‹$ï¼Œnå’Œmåˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯å¯¹åº”3ä¸ªå’Œ4ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦çš„æ•°å­—åœ¨åŸå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å‡ºç°çš„ä¸ªæ•°ã€‚
  • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(3^n4^m)$ï¼Œè§£çš„å¤§å°ï¼›å…¶ä¸­æ ˆçš„æ·±åº¦ä¸ºåŸå­—ç¬¦ä¸²é•¿åº¦ã€‚

è¿­ä»£

  • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(3^n4^m)$
  • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(3^n4^m)$
entry.summary:
é¢˜ç›®

Given a string containing digits from 2-9 inclusive, return all possible letter combinations that the number could represent.

A mapping of digit to letters (just like on the telephone buttons) is given below. Note that 1 does not map to any letters.

entry.title: 14.Longest Common Prefix
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®

Write a function to find the longest common prefix string amongst an array of strings.

If there is no common prefix, return an empty string "".

Example 1:

Example 2:

Note:

All given inputs are in lowercase letters a-z.

é¢˜è§£

  1. Horizontal scanningï¼Œä¾æ¬¡æ‰«æä¸¤ä¸ªå•è¯é—´çš„æœ€é•¿å‰ç¼€

    • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(nm)$ï¼Œnä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ•°é‡ï¼Œmä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¹³å‡é•¿åº¦
    • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(m)â€‹$

  2. Vertical scanningï¼ŒæŒ‰å­—ç¬¦ä¾æ¬¡æ‰«æï¼Œå¦‚æœæ‰€æœ‰strçš„ç¬¬iéƒ½æ˜¯è¿™ä¸€å­—ç¬¦é‚£ä¹ˆå°±åŠ å…¥å‰ç¼€

    • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(nm)$ï¼Œnä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ•°é‡ï¼Œmä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¹³å‡é•¿åº¦
    • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(m)$

  3. Divide and conquerï¼Œä¸¤ä¸¤æ¯”è¾ƒåå†æ¯”è¾ƒã€‚åœ¨è¿™é‡Œæ²¡æœ‰ä½“ç°å‡ºä¼˜åŠ¿çš„åŸå› æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸¤æ¯”è¾ƒçš„æˆæœ¬æ¯”è¾ƒä½ï¼ˆ$O(m)$ï¼‰ï¼Œæ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ä¹Ÿä¸æ¯”å¸¸è§„åšæ³•å¥½

    • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(nm)$ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä¸€å…±å¤§çº¦æœ‰$n/2 + n/4 + â€¦ + 1 = n = O(n)$æ¬¡æ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡æ¯”è¾ƒçš„å¤æ‚åº¦ä¸º$O(m)$
    • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(log(n))$ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯é€’å½’æ ˆçš„æ·±åº¦

  4. binary searchï¼Œæ‰¾åˆ°æœ€çŸ­çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²é•¿åº¦ï¼Œå¹¶å¯¹å¯èƒ½çš„é•¿åº¦è¿›è¡ŒäºŒåˆ†ï¼Œéå†ä»¥ç¡®è®¤è¿™ä¸ªé•¿åº¦æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯å…¬å…±å­åºåˆ—ã€‚

    • ï¼ˆäºŒåˆ†çš„å¥‡å¦™ç”¨æ³•ï¼‰
    • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(nmlog(m))$ï¼Œä¸€å…±è°ƒç”¨$O(log(m))$æ¬¡isCommonPrefixå‡½æ•°ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡è°ƒç”¨å¤æ‚åº¦ä¸º$O(nm)$
    • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(1)$

Follow upï¼šå¦‚æœéœ€è¦è®¡ç®—æŸå­—ç¬¦ä¸²så’Œstrså…±åŒçš„æœ€é•¿å‰ç¼€éœ€è¦å¤šæ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œåº”è¯¥å¦‚ä½•å®ç°ï¼Ÿå‡è®¾strsä¸å˜

  • ä½¿ç”¨trieã€‚
    • æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(nm)$åœ¨æ„å»ºæ ‘è¿‡ç¨‹ï¼Œ$O(m)$åœ¨æŸ¥æ‰¾è¿‡ç¨‹
    • ç©ºé—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O(nm)$ç”¨äºå­˜å‚¨trieæ ‘
entry.summary:
é¢˜ç›®

Write a function to find the longest common prefix string amongst an array of strings.

If there is no common prefix, return an empty string "".
